sub_title: Director of Education at Amsterdam University College
summary:
* Experience: Cultural anthropology | Qualitative methods | Ethnographic fieldwork | Research design | Indigenous people | Australia | Lecturing bachelor, master, research master students | Developing and coordinating higher degree courses | Individual student supervision | Organising seminars, panels and symposia | Reporting research findings to stakeholders.

* Personality: In the past decade I have lived and worked in the United States and Australia. This international experience, in particular my collaboration with Indigenous Australians in a remote community in the Western Desert, has shaped me to become an independent, flexible and social person. As lecturer, I combine these qualities with my academic training to offer my students an educational experience adapted to their individual learning needs and styles. At the same time, I encourage them to take ownership of their learning. 

* Ambition: Although trained as a researcher, my passion is higher education. I have been teaching young adults about academic writing, research methods in the social sciences and various social and cultural theories. What I love about lecturing is solving didactic puzzles: what approach to communicating ideas and knowledge works best in what context, and for whom? How do I adjust my teaching to suit the learning style of a particular student? I enjoy thinking about examination criteria and assignments for courses and like to read literature on education to advance my expertise. In the near future, I aspire to a role in which I can become more involved in organising and coordinating a series of higher education courses (i.e. coordinating at a higher level), without losing contact with students.

projects.title: The View of Self / Blak on blak
projects.description: During this edition of Framer Framed co-organised by the Australian magazine Artlink on the occasion of the publication of its special issue Blak on blak, I gave an introduction on the positioning of Aboriginal Art in the Netherlands. Lecture held during the Framer Framed program The View of Self / Blak on blak at the AAMU – Museum for Contemporary Aboriginal Art in Utrecht, the Netherlands, May 30, 2010.

authors.headline: Director of Education at Amsterdam University College

profile_positions.description:
Responsibilities:
* Coordinate undergraduate and graduate courses 
* Teach courses on theory, method and academic skills to bachelor, master and research master students
* Supervise bachelor and master theses
* Curriculum development
profile_positions.title: Docent Culturele Antropologie en Ontwikkelingsstudies

profile_positions.description:
Responsibilities:
* Organized interdisciplinary research project (ethics approval, federal government permissions, involvement Indigenous not-for profit organisations)
* Conducted ethnographic research, using methods such as interviews, participant observation and questionnaires
* Organized symposium “2013 Research Exchange: Remote Indigenous enterprises in Arts and Tourism”
* Reported research progress and key findings to funding bodies, stakeholders, the academic community and the general public, both orally and in writing
* Taught guest lectures to undergraduate students
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow

profile_positions.description: I taught one half of a full semester course on Oceanic Arts, focusing on Indigenous Australian art. As part of this position, I developed a new curriculum and syllabus. The course was offered to higher degree students by MICA's Liberal Arts Department.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer Oceanic Arts: Australia and Melanesia

profile_positions.location: Department of Anthropology and Development Studies
profile_positions.description:
Initiated a project to conduct research in Australia’s urban centres on the subject of contemporary photography and video art created by commonly disregarded Aboriginal Australians. Applied for and obtained 150.000 euro in funding from the Dutch and Australian federal governments. Conducted ethnographic fieldwork with Aboriginal Australians and non-Aboriginal art professionals in Melbourne, Adelaide and Sydney. Used in-depth interviews, informal conversations, photo-elicitation, participant observation and survey research as research methods. 

Presented research findings as part of 5 international conferences. Published 3 articles in peer-reviewed journals. Published 11 non peer-reviewed articles. Wrote a 500-page dissertation. Taught 4 guest lectures to BA students in anthropology. Supervised 3 BA and MA theses. Taught a 12-week course on Pacific Studies to 10 BA3 students. Independently developed an introductory course on Aboriginal art and presented this course to 40 members of the Dutch general public on 2 occasions.

Awarded by the Radboud University Nijmegen with the Frye Stipend 2009 as one of ten of the university’s most promising female junior researchers.  

Co-organizer of the 2008 annual conference of the Nijmegen School of Social and Cultural Research. Organized the 2008-2009 seminar series of the Department of Anthropology and Development Studies of the Radboud University. Initiated a reading group for Ph.D candidates in Anthropology. Contributed as a Ph.D representative to the meetings of the board of the Nijmegen School of Social and Cultural Research.
profile_positions.title: Ph.D Candidate / Junior Researcher

profile_positions.description: Developed a project that focused on identifying the causes behind the academic failure of elementary students in remote Aboriginal schools. Carried out four months of ethnographic fieldwork in Australia, with Pitjantjatjara Aboriginal people based in the remote desert community of Fregon. Utilized in-depth interviews, informal conversations, survey research and participant observation as research methods. Worked as a visiting student for the Centre for Aboriginal Economic Policy Research, the Australian National University, in Canberra, Australia. Used time in Canberra to carry out literature review. Wrote a 100-page MA thesis based on research results. This thesis has been used by the director of Fregon Anangu School for the purpose of training teachers. Published findings in a non peer-reviewed article.
profile_positions.title: MA Research Project, carried out for the Department of Anthropology and Development Studies

company.name: VDA Home Care, Veghel, the Netherlands

profile_positions.company: VDA Home Care, Veghel, the Netherlands
profile_positions.description: Worked with elderly people, persons suffering from a variety of mental illnesses, and physically impaired young people. Responsible for cleaning their houses, running errands, and completing administrative duties. Developed personal relationships with Dutch individuals of a range of different cultural, social, and economic backgrounds. Provided clients with companionship and, where necessary, psychological support.
profile_positions.title: Caregiver (part time)

profile_positions.location: Gouda, the Netherlands; Alphen a/d Rijn, the Netherlands
profile_positions.description:
1998-2002: Salesperson

Responsible for assisting the public (children and adults) with selecting the right kinds of shoes. Worked to maintain a fully stocked store at all times. Work as cashier. Awarded with a prize, together with other team members, for making the top-3 of Toe shoes stores with the most sales recorded over a period of several months

2001 (3 months): Interim assistant manager

Responsible for personnel management. Developed and implemented short-term sales strategy. Sold shoes to the public. Maintained a fully stocked store at all times. Worked as cashier. Responsible for opening and closing the store every day, and for depositing money in store’s bank account. Resolved customer service problems. Received a bonus for realizing a minimum of 1500 euro in weekly shoe sales on several occasions.
profile_positions.title: Salesperson (part time) + interim assistant manager (full time)

company.name: AAMU Museum of contemporary Aboriginal art

volunteer_experiences.description: In the early years I performed guided tours through the exhibitions with museum visitors. I also worked in the museum cafe and behind the ticketing desk. In the final years, I focused on presenting the guided tours to visitors.
